error.signature: Warning: Can't perform a React state update on an unmounted component.
error.regex: Can't perform a React state update on an unmounted component|Can't perform a React state update on a component that hasn't mounted yet

verdict.summary: Async operation (fetch, timer, subscription) completes after component unmounts and tries to call setState. Warning removed in React 18.3+ but the memory leak remains.

dead_ends.action: Use an isMounted ref flag to guard setState calls
dead_ends.why_fails: This is an anti-pattern that masks the real issue; the async operation still runs and wastes resources. React docs explicitly discourage this.

dead_ends.action: Ignore the warning since React 18.3+ removed it
dead_ends.why_fails: The warning is gone but the underlying memory leak and wasted network requests remain

workarounds.action: Use AbortController in useEffect cleanup to cancel fetch requests on unmount
workarounds.how: useEffect(() => { const controller = new AbortController(); fetch(url, { signal: controller.signal }).then(...); return () => controller.abort(); }, [url]);

workarounds.action: Clear timers and unsubscribe in the useEffect cleanup function
workarounds.how: useEffect(() => { const id = setInterval(fn, 1000); return () => clearInterval(id); }, []);
workarounds.condition: When the async operation is a timer or subscription

leads_to.condition: When the fix is incomplete and only addresses setState but not the underlying resource leak

preceded_by.condition: When missing dependencies cause the effect to not clean up properly on re-runs

frequently_confused_with.distinction: The existing cannot-update-unmounted canon covers the same base warning; this canon specifically addresses the async-operation pattern causing the unmounted update
